Summarize Selected Numeric Columns in a Data Frame

sum_cols.Rd

This function computes the column-wise sum of user-specified numeric columns in a given data frame. It retains all original columns, appending a "Total" row at the bottom for selected columns. Non-numeric columns remain unchanged, with NA added to the "Total" row.

This function computes the column-wise sum of user-specified numeric columns in a given data frame. It retains all original columns, appending a "Total" row at the bottom for selected columns. Non-numeric columns remain unchanged, with NA added to the "Total" row.

Usage

sum_cols(df, cols_to_sum)

sum_cols(df, cols_to_sum)

Arguments

df

A data frame containing numeric and non-numeric columns.

cols_to_sum

A character vector specifying the names of numeric columns to be summed.

Value

A modified data frame where the specified numeric columns have an additional "Total" row, while all other columns remain intact.

A modified data frame where the specified numeric columns have an additional "Total" row, while all other columns remain intact.

Details

  • This function supports numeric, factor, and character columns.

  • Character columns in cols_to_sum are automatically converted to numeric if possible.

  • Non-numeric columns are preserved and filled with NA in the "Total" row.

  • If cols_to_sum contains invalid column names, the function returns an error.

  • This function supports numeric, factor, and character columns.

  • Character columns in cols_to_sum are automatically converted to numeric if possible.

  • Non-numeric columns are preserved and filled with NA in the "Total" row.

  • If cols_to_sum contains invalid column names, the function returns an error.

Examples

df <- data.frame(
  ID = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5),
  Name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie", "David", "Eve"),
  Age = c(25, 30, 22, 28, 35),
  Income = c("50000", "60000", "45000", "70000", "80000"),
  Status = as.factor(c("Single", "Married", "Single", "Married", "Single")),
  Score = c(85.5, 90.2, 78.0, 88.8, 92.3)
)
sum_cols(df, c("Age", "Income", "Score"))
#>       ID    Name Age Income  Status Score
#> 1      1   Alice  25  50000  Single  85.5
#> 2      2     Bob  30  60000 Married  90.2
#> 3      3 Charlie  22  45000  Single  78.0
#> 4      4   David  28  70000 Married  88.8
#> 5      5     Eve  35  80000  Single  92.3
#> Total NA    <NA> 140 305000    <NA> 434.8

df <- data.frame(
  ID = c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5),
  Name = c("Alice", "Bob", "Charlie", "David", "Eve"),
  Age = c(25, 30, 22, 28, 35),
  Income = c("50000", "60000", "45000", "70000", "80000"),
  Status = as.factor(c("Single", "Married", "Single", "Married", "Single")),
  Score = c(85.5, 90.2, 78.0, 88.8, 92.3)
)
sum_cols(df, c("Age", "Income", "Score"))
#>       ID    Name Age Income  Status Score
#> 1      1   Alice  25  50000  Single  85.5
#> 2      2     Bob  30  60000 Married  90.2
#> 3      3 Charlie  22  45000  Single  78.0
#> 4      4   David  28  70000 Married  88.8
#> 5      5     Eve  35  80000  Single  92.3
#> Total NA    <NA> 140 305000    <NA> 434.8
